natural problem:
The number
\[\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ\]is expressed in the form $r \, \text{cis } \theta$, where $r > 0$ and $0^\circ \le \theta < 360^\circ$.  Find $\theta$ in degrees.
natural solution: First, we note that the angle measures form an arithmetic sequence whose average is $111^\circ$.

&= [\text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ)] \text{cis } 111^\circ. \end{align}The terms of the sum \[\text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ)\]can be paired into terms of the form $\text{cis } n^\circ + \text{cis } (-n)^\circ$, and
\begin{align} \text{cis } n^\circ + \text{cis } (-n)^\circ &= \cos n^\circ + i \sin n^\circ + \cos n^\circ - i \sin n^\circ \\ &= 2 \cos n^\circ, \end{align}which is real.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes r theta :: real
assumes h0 : "r > 0"
and h1 : "0 \<le> theta \<and> theta < 360"
and h2 : "sum (\<lambda> i. cis i) {75,83,91,...,147} = r * cis theta"
shows  "theta = 111"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The number
\[\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ\]is expressed in the form $r \, \text{cis } \theta$, where $r > 0$ and $0^\circ \le \theta < 360^\circ$.  Find $\theta$ in degrees. The final Answer is 111^\circ
 ### Proof
 First, we note that the angle measures form an arithmetic sequence whose average is $111^\circ$.
 We have that \begin{align} &\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ  \\ &= \frac{\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ}{\text{cis } 111^\circ} \cdot \text{cis } 111^\circ \\
 &= [\text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ)] \text{cis } 111^\circ. \end{align}The terms of the sum \[\text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ)\]can be paired into terms of the form $\text{cis } n^\circ + \text{cis } (-n)^\circ$, and
 \begin{align} \text{cis } n^\circ + \text{cis } (-n)^\circ &= \cos n^\circ + i \sin n^\circ + \cos n^\circ - i \sin n^\circ \\ &= 2 \cos n^\circ, \end{align}which is real.
 Therefore, \[\text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ)\]is real.
 Let \[r = \text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ).\]Then \[\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ = r \, \text{cis } 111^\circ,\]so $\theta = \boxed{111^\circ}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes r theta :: real
assumes h0 : "r > 0"
and h1 : "0 \<le> theta \<and> theta < 360"
and h2 : "sum (\<lambda> i. cis i) {75,83,91,...,147} = r * cis theta"
shows  "theta = 111"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given that $r > 0$ and $0 \leq \theta < 360$, if the sum of the complex numbers represented by the angle $i$ in degrees for $i$ in the set $\{75, 83, 91, ..., 147\}$ is equal to a complex number in polar form $r * cis(\theta)$, find the value of $\theta$. The final answer is $111$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes theta :: real and r :: real
assumes h0 : "r > 0"
and h1 : "0 \<le> theta \<and> theta < 360"
and h2 : "(\<Sum>i\<in>{75,83..147}. cis (rad_of_deg i)) = r * cis (rad_of_deg theta)"
shows  "theta = 111"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The number
\[\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ\]is expressed in the form $r \, \text{cis } \theta$, where $r > 0$ and $0^\circ \le \theta < 360^\circ$.  Find $\theta$ in degrees. The final Answer is 111^\circ
 ### Proof
 First, we note that the angle measures form an arithmetic sequence whose average is $111^\circ$.
 We have that \begin{align} &\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ  \\ &= \frac{\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ}{\text{cis } 111^\circ} \cdot \text{cis } 111^\circ \\
 &= [\text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ)] \text{cis } 111^\circ. \end{align}The terms of the sum \[\text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ)\]can be paired into terms of the form $\text{cis } n^\circ + \text{cis } (-n)^\circ$, and
 \begin{align} \text{cis } n^\circ + \text{cis } (-n)^\circ &= \cos n^\circ + i \sin n^\circ + \cos n^\circ - i \sin n^\circ \\ &= 2 \cos n^\circ, \end{align}which is real.
 Therefore, \[\text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ)\]is real.
 Let \[r = \text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ).\]Then \[\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ = r \, \text{cis } 111^\circ,\]so $\theta = \boxed{111^\circ}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes theta :: real and r :: real
assumes h0 : "r > 0"
and h1 : "0 \<le> theta \<and> theta < 360"
and h2 : "(\<Sum>i\<in>{75,83..147}. cis (rad_of_deg i)) = r * cis (rad_of_deg theta)"
shows  "theta = 111"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Given a positive radius $r$ and an angle $\theta$ between 0 and 360 degrees, if the sum of $cis$ of the degrees converted to radians for all degrees from 75 to 147 with a step of 8 equals to $r$ times $cis$ of the angle $\theta$ converted to radians, then find the value of $\theta$. The final Answer is 111.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes cis :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. 75 + n * 8 \<le> 147 \<longrightarrow> cis (75 + n * 8) = r * cis \<theta>"
shows  "\<theta> = 111"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The number
\[\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ\]is expressed in the form $r \, \text{cis } \theta$, where $r > 0$ and $0^\circ \le \theta < 360^\circ$.  Find $\theta$ in degrees. The final Answer is 111^\circ
 ### Proof
 First, we note that the angle measures form an arithmetic sequence whose average is $111^\circ$.
 We have that \begin{align} &\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ  \\ &= \frac{\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ}{\text{cis } 111^\circ} \cdot \text{cis } 111^\circ \\
 &= [\text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ)] \text{cis } 111^\circ. \end{align}The terms of the sum \[\text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ)\]can be paired into terms of the form $\text{cis } n^\circ + \text{cis } (-n)^\circ$, and
 \begin{align} \text{cis } n^\circ + \text{cis } (-n)^\circ &= \cos n^\circ + i \sin n^\circ + \cos n^\circ - i \sin n^\circ \\ &= 2 \cos n^\circ, \end{align}which is real.
 Therefore, \[\text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ)\]is real.
 Let \[r = \text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ).\]Then \[\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ = r \, \text{cis } 111^\circ,\]so $\theta = \boxed{111^\circ}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes cis :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. 75 + n * 8 \<le> 147 \<longrightarrow> cis (75 + n * 8) = r * cis \<theta>"
shows  "\<theta> = 111"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Find the value of θ such that for any real number n, if 75 + 8n is less than or equal to 147, then the circular function of 75 + 8n equals r times the circular function of θ. The final answer is θ equals 111.

theorem
fixes r theta :: real

(* ### Problem

 Therefore, \[\text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ)\]is real.
 Let \[r = \text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ).\]Then \[\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ = r \, \text{cis } 111^\circ,\]so $\theta = \boxed{111^\circ}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes r theta :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. cis (75 + 8 * n) = r * cis theta"
and h1 : "0 \<le> theta"
and h2 : "theta < 360"
shows  "theta = 111"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Find the value of $\theta$ in the range $0 \le \theta < 360$ such that the complex number $cis(75 + 8n)$ can be expressed in the form $r \cdot cis(\theta)$ for all integers $n$. The final answer is $\theta = 111$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes cis :: "real \<Rightarrow> complex"
assumes h0 : "cis = (\<lambda> x. Complex (cos x) (sin x))"
and h1 : "sum cis {75, 83, 91, ..., 147} = r * cis \<theta>"
and h2 : "r > 0"
and h3 : "0 \<le> \<theta> \<and> \<theta> < 360"
shows  "\<theta> = 111"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The number
\[\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ\]is expressed in the form $r \, \text{cis } \theta$, where $r > 0$ and $0^\circ \le \theta < 360^\circ$.  Find $\theta$ in degrees. The final Answer is 111^\circ
 ### Proof
 First, we note that the angle measures form an arithmetic sequence whose average is $111^\circ$.
 We have that \begin{align} &\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ  \\ &= \frac{\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ}{\text{cis } 111^\circ} \cdot \text{cis } 111^\circ \\

 Therefore, \[\text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ)\]is real.
 Let \[r = \text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ).\]Then \[\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ = r \, \text{cis } 111^\circ,\]so $\theta = \boxed{111^\circ}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes cis :: "real \<Rightarrow> complex"
assumes h0 : "cis = (\<lambda> x. Complex (cos x) (sin x))"
and h1 : "sum cis {75, 83, 91, ..., 147} = r * cis \<theta>"
and h2 : "r > 0"
and h3 : "0 \<le> \<theta> \<and> \<theta> < 360"
shows  "\<theta> = 111"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Given a complex function cis defined as cis(x) = cos(x) + sin(x)i, find the argument (in degrees) of the sum of cis of a set of real numbers starting from 75, incrementing by 8 until 147 inclusive. The sum is equal to a complex number in polar form with positive magnitude r and argument θ (0 ≤ θ < 360 degrees). The final answer is θ = 111.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes cis :: "real \<Rightarrow> complex"
and theta :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. cis n = Complex (cos n) (sin n)"
and h1 : "sum cis {75,83,91,...,147} = r * cis (theta)"
and h2 : "0 \<le> theta"
and h3 : "theta < 360"
shows  "theta = 111"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The number
\[\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ\]is expressed in the form $r \, \text{cis } \theta$, where $r > 0$ and $0^\circ \le \theta < 360^\circ$.  Find $\theta$ in degrees. The final Answer is 111^\circ
 ### Proof
 First, we note that the angle measures form an arithmetic sequence whose average is $111^\circ$.
 We have that \begin{align} &\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ  \\ &= \frac{\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ}{\text{cis } 111^\circ} \cdot \text{cis } 111^\circ \\
 &= [\text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ)] \text{cis } 111^\circ. \end{align}The terms of the sum \[\text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ)\]can be paired into terms of the form $\text{cis } n^\circ + \text{cis } (-n)^\circ$, and
 \begin{align} \text{cis } n^\circ + \text{cis } (-n)^\circ &= \cos n^\circ + i \sin n^\circ + \cos n^\circ - i \sin n^\circ \\ &= 2 \cos n^\circ, \end{align}which is real.
 Therefore, \[\text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ)\]is real.
 Let \[r = \text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ).\]Then \[\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ = r \, \text{cis } 111^\circ,\]so $\theta = \boxed{111^\circ}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes cis :: "real \<Rightarrow> complex"
and theta :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. cis n = Complex (cos n) (sin n)"
and h1 : "sum cis {75,83,91,...,147} = r * cis (theta)"
and h2 : "0 \<le> theta"
and h3 : "theta < 360"
shows  "theta = 111"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: The function $cis(n)$ is defined as $cis(n) = cos(n) + sin(n)i$ for all real numbers $n$. Given that the sum of $cis(n)$ for $n$ in the set {75, 83, 91, ..., 147} is equal to $r * cis(\theta)$, and $\theta$ is a real number in the range $0 \leq \theta < 360$, find the value of $\theta$. The final answer is 111.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> complex" and theta r :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. f n = cis (n * 8 + 67)"
and h1 : "(\<Sum> n \<le> 10. f n) = r * cis theta"
and h2 : "r > 0"
and h3 : "theta \<ge> 0"
and h4 : "theta < 360"
shows  "theta = 111"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The number
\[\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ\]is expressed in the form $r \, \text{cis } \theta$, where $r > 0$ and $0^\circ \le \theta < 360^\circ$.  Find $\theta$ in degrees. The final Answer is 111^\circ
 ### Proof
 First, we note that the angle measures form an arithmetic sequence whose average is $111^\circ$.
 We have that \begin{align} &\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ  \\ &= \frac{\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ}{\text{cis } 111^\circ} \cdot \text{cis } 111^\circ \\
 &= [\text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ)] \text{cis } 111^\circ. \end{align}The terms of the sum \[\text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ)\]can be paired into terms of the form $\text{cis } n^\circ + \text{cis } (-n)^\circ$, and
 \begin{align} \text{cis } n^\circ + \text{cis } (-n)^\circ &= \cos n^\circ + i \sin n^\circ + \cos n^\circ - i \sin n^\circ \\ &= 2 \cos n^\circ, \end{align}which is real.
 Therefore, \[\text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ)\]is real.
 Let \[r = \text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ).\]Then \[\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ = r \, \text{cis } 111^\circ,\]so $\theta = \boxed{111^\circ}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> complex" and theta r :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. f n = cis (n * 8 + 67)"
and h1 : "(\<Sum> n \<le> 10. f n) = r * cis theta"
and h2 : "r > 0"
and h3 : "theta \<ge> 0"
and h4 : "theta < 360"
shows  "theta = 111"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Consider a function $f$ defined as $f(n) = cis(n*8 + 67)$ for all real numbers $n$. If the sum of the values of $f(n)$ for $n$ up to 10 equals $r * cis(\theta)$, where $r$ is a positive real number and $\theta$ is a real number between 0 and 360 degrees, find the value of $\theta$. The final answer is 111 degrees.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes r θ :: real and cis :: "real \<Rightarrow> complex"
assumes h0 : "r > 0"
and h1 : "0 \<le> θ \<and> θ < 360"
and h2 : "\<forall> i. 75 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 147 \<and> i mod 8 = 0 \<longrightarrow> cis i"
and h3 : "r * cis θ = sum (\<lambda>i. cis i) {i. 75 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 147 \<and> i mod 8 = 0}"
shows  "θ = 111"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The number
\[\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ\]is expressed in the form $r \, \text{cis } \theta$, where $r > 0$ and $0^\circ \le \theta < 360^\circ$.  Find $\theta$ in degrees. The final Answer is 111^\circ
 ### Proof
 First, we note that the angle measures form an arithmetic sequence whose average is $111^\circ$.
 We have that \begin{align} &\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ  \\ &= \frac{\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ}{\text{cis } 111^\circ} \cdot \text{cis } 111^\circ \\
 &= [\text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ)] \text{cis } 111^\circ. \end{align}The terms of the sum \[\text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ)\]can be paired into terms of the form $\text{cis } n^\circ + \text{cis } (-n)^\circ$, and
 \begin{align} \text{cis } n^\circ + \text{cis } (-n)^\circ &= \cos n^\circ + i \sin n^\circ + \cos n^\circ - i \sin n^\circ \\ &= 2 \cos n^\circ, \end{align}which is real.
 Therefore, \[\text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ)\]is real.
 Let \[r = \text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ).\]Then \[\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ = r \, \text{cis } 111^\circ,\]so $\theta = \boxed{111^\circ}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes r θ :: real and cis :: "real \<Rightarrow> complex"
assumes h0 : "r > 0"
and h1 : "0 \<le> θ \<and> θ < 360"
and h2 : "\<forall> i. 75 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 147 \<and> i mod 8 = 0 \<longrightarrow> cis i"
and h3 : "r * cis θ = sum (\<lambda>i. cis i) {i. 75 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 147 \<and> i mod 8 = 0}"
shows  "θ = 111"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Given a positive real number $r$ and a real number $\theta$ in the range $0 \leq \theta < 360$. Suppose for all integers $i$ such that $75 \leq i \leq 147$ and $i$ is a multiple of 8, we have $cis(i)$ (where $cis$ is a complex number function). If $r \times cis(\theta)$ is equal to the sum of $cis(i)$ over all such $i$, what is the value of $\theta$? The final answer is $111$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes r :: real and theta :: real and cis :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "r > 0"
and h1 : "theta >= 0"
and h2 : "theta < 360"
and h3 : "cis 75 + cis 83 + cis 91 + ... + cis 147 = r * cis theta"
shows  "theta = 111"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The number
\[\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ\]is expressed in the form $r \, \text{cis } \theta$, where $r > 0$ and $0^\circ \le \theta < 360^\circ$.  Find $\theta$ in degrees. The final Answer is 111^\circ
 ### Proof
 First, we note that the angle measures form an arithmetic sequence whose average is $111^\circ$.
 We have that \begin{align} &\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ  \\ &= \frac{\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ}{\text{cis } 111^\circ} \cdot \text{cis } 111^\circ \\
 &= [\text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ)] \text{cis } 111^\circ. \end{align}The terms of the sum \[\text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ)\]can be paired into terms of the form $\text{cis } n^\circ + \text{cis } (-n)^\circ$, and
 \begin{align} \text{cis } n^\circ + \text{cis } (-n)^\circ &= \cos n^\circ + i \sin n^\circ + \cos n^\circ - i \sin n^\circ \\ &= 2 \cos n^\circ, \end{align}which is real.
 Therefore, \[\text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ)\]is real.
 Let \[r = \text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ).\]Then \[\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ = r \, \text{cis } 111^\circ,\]so $\theta = \boxed{111^\circ}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes r :: real and theta :: real and cis :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "r > 0"
and h1 : "theta >= 0"
and h2 : "theta < 360"
and h3 : "cis 75 + cis 83 + cis 91 + ... + cis 147 = r * cis theta"
shows  "theta = 111"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Given that $r > 0$ and $0 \leq \theta < 360$, find the value of $\theta$ such that the sum of the complex numbers $cis(75)$, $cis(83)$, $cis(91)$, ..., $cis(147)$ equals $r * cis(\theta)$. The final answer is $\theta = 111$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes r theta :: real and cis :: "real \<Rightarrow> complex"
assumes h0 : "cis = (\<lambda> x. Complex (cos x) (sin x))"
and h1 : "r > 0"
and h2 : "0 \<le> theta"
and h3 : "theta < 360"
and h4 : "cis 75 + cis 83 + cis 91 + ... + cis 147 = r * cis theta"
shows  "theta = 111"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The number
\[\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ\]is expressed in the form $r \, \text{cis } \theta$, where $r > 0$ and $0^\circ \le \theta < 360^\circ$.  Find $\theta$ in degrees. The final Answer is 111^\circ
 ### Proof
 First, we note that the angle measures form an arithmetic sequence whose average is $111^\circ$.
 We have that \begin{align} &\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ  \\ &= \frac{\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ}{\text{cis } 111^\circ} \cdot \text{cis } 111^\circ \\
 &= [\text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ)] \text{cis } 111^\circ. \end{align}The terms of the sum \[\text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ)\]can be paired into terms of the form $\text{cis } n^\circ + \text{cis } (-n)^\circ$, and
 \begin{align} \text{cis } n^\circ + \text{cis } (-n)^\circ &= \cos n^\circ + i \sin n^\circ + \cos n^\circ - i \sin n^\circ \\ &= 2 \cos n^\circ, \end{align}which is real.
 Therefore, \[\text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ)\]is real.
 Let \[r = \text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ).\]Then \[\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ = r \, \text{cis } 111^\circ,\]so $\theta = \boxed{111^\circ}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes r theta :: real and cis :: "real \<Rightarrow> complex"
assumes h0 : "cis = (\<lambda> x. Complex (cos x) (sin x))"
and h1 : "r > 0"
and h2 : "0 \<le> theta"
and h3 : "theta < 360"
and h4 : "cis 75 + cis 83 + cis 91 + ... + cis 147 = r * cis theta"
shows  "theta = 111"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Find the argument of the sum of the complex numbers $cis(75)$, $cis(83)$, $cis(91)$, ..., $cis(147)$, where $cis(x) = cos(x) + isin(x)$. If the sum is expressed in polar form as $r * cis(\theta)$, with $r > 0$ and $0 \leq \theta < 360$, find the value of $\theta$. The final answer is $\theta = 111$.
